titleStmt.title: A Machine-Readable Version of George a Greene, the Pinner of Wakefield (1599)

publicationStmt.publisher: A pleasant conceyted comedie of George a Greene, the pinner of VVakefield As it was sundry times acted by the seruants of the right Honourable the Earle of Sussex. Imprinted at London : By Simon Stafford, for Cuthbert Burby: and are to be sold at his shop neere the Royall Exchange, 1599.

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
George a Greene. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1599. Date first performed: 1587-1593.
Based on the LION version of STC12212, 1599, checked against page images from the EEBO text

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Robin Hood Earl of Kendall Shoemaker Lord Bonfild Sir Gilbert Armstrong Nicholas Mannering Iustice Townsmen George a Greene Cuddie Olde Musgroue Grime Bettris King James Ned Marian Iane a Barley Scarlet Ienkin Willie King Edward Warwick Much Omnes Iohn Taylour Messenger

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Enter the Earle of Kendall, with him the Lord Bonfild, Sir Gilbert Armestrong, and Iohn.

sp.speaker: Earle of Kendall.
sp.l: Welcome to Bradford, martial gentlemen,
Lord Bonfild and sir Gilbert Armstrong both,
And all my troops, even to my basest groom,
Courage and welcome; for the day is ours:
our cause is good, it is for the lands avail:
Then let us fight, and die for Englands good.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: we will, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kendall.
sp.l: As I am Henrie Momford Kendals Earl,
You honour me with this assent of yours,
And here upon my sword I make protest,
for to relieve the poor, or die myself :
And know, my Lords, that Iames the King of Scots,
Wars hard upon the borders of this land:
Here is his Post: say, Iohn Taylour,
What news with King Iames?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: War, my Lord: tell, and good news I trow:
for king Iame vows to meet you the twenty-sixth of this month,
God willing, marie doth he sir.

sp.speaker: Kendall.
sp.l: My friends, you see what we have to win.
Well, Iohn, commend me to king Iames,
And tell him I will meet him the twenty-sixth of this month,
And all the rest: and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Kendall.
sp.l: Bonfild why standest thou as a man in dumps?
Courage: for if I win, I will make thee Duke:
I Henry Momford will be King myself,
And I will make thee Duke of Lancaster,
And Gilbert Armestrong Lord of Doncaster.

sp.speaker: Bonfild.
sp.l: Nothing, my Lord, makes me amazed at all,
But that our soldiers finds our victuals scant:
we must make havoc of those country Swains:
for so will the rest tremble and be afraid,
And humbly send provision to your camp.

sp.speaker: Gilb.
sp.l: My Lord Bonfild gives good advice,
They make a scorn and stand upon the King:
so what is brought, is sent from them perforce;
ask Mannering else.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: What sayst thou, Mannering?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: When as I showed your high commission,
They made this answer,
only to send provision for your horses.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Well, hie thee to Wakefield, bid the Town
to send me all provision that I want;
lest I, like martial Tamberlaine, lay waste
Their bordering Countries,
And leaving none alive that contradicts my Commission.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Let me alone, my Lord, I will make them
Vail their plumes: for whatsoever he be,
The proudest Knight, Justice, or other, that gainsayeth
Your word, I will clap him fast, to make the rest to fear.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: do so Nick: hie thee thither presently,
And let us hear of thee again tomorrow .

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: will you not remove, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: no: I will lie at Bradford all this night,
And all the next: come, Bonfield, let us go,
And listen out some bonny lasses here.

body.stage: Enter the Iustice, a Townesman, George a Greene, and Sir Nicholas Mannering with his Commission.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.l: Master. Mannering, stand aside, whilst we confer
What is best to do.
Townsmen of Wakefield, the Earl of Kendall
Here hath sent for victuals;
And in aiding him, we show ourselves
no less than traitors to the King:
Therefore let me hear, Townsmen,
What is your consents.

sp.speaker: Townes.
sp.l: even as you please we are all content.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.l: Then Master. Mannering we are resolved.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.l: Marry sir, thus.
we will send the Earl of Kendall no victuals,
Because he is a traitor to the King;
And in aiding him we show ourselves no less.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Why, men of Wakefield, are you waxen mad;
that present danger cannot whet your wits,
Wisely to make provision of your selves?
The Earl is thirty thousand men strong in power,
And what town so ever him resist,
He lays it flat and level with the ground:
Ye silly men, you seek your own decay:
Therefore send my Lord such provision as he wants,
so he will spare your town, and come no nearer
Wakefield than he is.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.l: Master Mannering, you have your answer,
You may be gone.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Well, Woodroffe, for so I guess is thy name,
I will make thee curse thy overthwart denial;
And all that sit upon the bench this day,
Shall rue the hour they have withstood my Lords Commission.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.l: do thy worst, we fear thee not.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: See you these seals? before you pass the town,
I will have all things my Lord doth want,
in spite of you.

sp.speaker: George a Greene.
sp.l: Proud dapper Jack, vail bonnet to The bench,
that represents the person of the King;
Or sirrah, I will lay thy head before thy sect.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Why, who art thou?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Why, I am George a Greene,
True liegeman to my King,
who scorns that men of such esteem as these,
Should brooke the braves of any traitorous squire:
You of the bench, and you my fellow friends,
Neighbours, we subjects all unto the King,
we are English borne, and therefore Edwards friends,
Vowed unto him even in our mothers womb,
our minds to God, our hearts unto our King,
our wealth, our homage, and our carcasses,
Be all King Edwards: then sirrah, we have
Nothing left for traitors, but our swords,
Whetted to bathe them in your bloods,
And die against you, before we send you any victuals.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.l: Well spoken, George a Greene.

sp.speaker: Townes.
sp.l: Pray let George a Greene speak for us.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Sirrah you get no victuals here,
Not if a hoof of beef would save your lives.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Fellow, I stand amazed at thy presumption:
Why, what art thou that darest gainsay my Lord,
Knowing his mighty puissance and his stroke?
Why, my friend, I come not barely of myself:
for see, I have a large Commission.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Let me see it, sirrah.
Whose seals be these?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: This is the Earl of Kendals seal at arms,
This Lord Charnel Bonfields,
And this sir Gilbert Armestrongs.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: I tell thee, sirrah, did good King Edwards son
Seal a commission against the King his father,
Thus would I tear it in despite of him,

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Being traitor to my Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What? hast thou torn my Lord; Commission?
Thou shalt rue it, and so shall all Wakefield.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: What, are you in choler? I will give you pills
to cool your stomach.
Seest thou these seals?
Now by my fathers soul, which was a yeoman,
When he was alive, eat them,
Or eat my daggers point, proud squire.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But thou dost but jest, I hope.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Sure that shall you see, before we two part.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Well, and there be no remedy, so George,
One is gone: I pray thee no more now.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: O sir, if one be good, the others cannot hurt.
so sir, now you may go tell the Earl of Kendall,
Although I have rent his large Commission,
Yet of courtesy I have sent all his seals
back again by you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Well, sir, I will do your arrant.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: now let him tell his Lord, that he hath
Spoke with George a Greene,
Right pinner of merry Wakefield town,
that hath physic for a fool,
Pills for a traitor that doth wrong his Sovereign.
Are you content with this that I have done?

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.l: Aye , content, George:
for highly hast thou honoured Wakefield town,
in cutting of proud Mannering so short.
Come, thou shalt be my welcome guest today ;
for well thou hast deserved reward and favour.

body.stage: Enter olde Musgroue, and yong Cuddie his sonne.

sp.speaker: Cuddie.
sp.l: now gentle father list unto thy son,
And for my mothers love,
that erst was blithe and bonny in thine eye,
Grant one petition that I shall demand.

sp.speaker: Olde Musgroue.
sp.l: What is that, my Cuddie?

sp.speaker: Cuddie.
sp.l: Father, you know the ancient enmity of late,
between the Musgroues and the wily Scots,
Whereof they have oath,
Not to leave one alive that strides a lance.
O Father, you are old, and waning age unto the grave:
Old William Musgroue, which whilom was thought,
The bravest horseman in all Westmerland,
Is weak, and forced to stay his arm upon a staff,
that erst could wield a lance:
Then, gentle Father, resign the hold to me;
give arms to youth, and honour unto age.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Avaunt, false hearted boy, my joints do quake,
even with anguish of thy very words.
Hath William Musgroue seen an hundred years?
have I been feared and dreaded of the Scots,
that when they heard my name in any road,
They fled away, and posted thence amain?
And shall I die with shame now in mine age?
no, Cuddie, no, thus resolve I,
Here have I lived, and here will Musgroue die.

body.stage: Enter Lord Bonfild, Sir Gilbert Armestrong, M.Grime, and Bettris his daughter.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Now, gentle Grime, God a mercy for our good cheer,
our fare was royal, and our welcome great;
And since so kindly thou hast entertained us,
If we return with happy victory,
we will deal as friendly with thee in recompense.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.l: Your welcome was but duty, gentle Lord:
for wherefore have we given us our wealth,
But to make our betters welcome when they come?
O, this goes hard when traitors must be flattered:
But life is sweet, and I cannot withstand it.
God (I hope) will revenge the quarrel of my King.

sp.speaker: Gilb.
sp.l: What said you, Grime?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.l: I say, sir Gilbert, looking on my daughter,
I curse the hour that ere I got the girl:
for sir, she may have many wealthy suitors,
And yet she disdains them all, to have
Poor George a Greene unto her husband.

sp.speaker: Bonfild.
sp.l: on that, good Grime, I am talking with thy Daughter;
But she in quirks and quiddities of love,
Sets me to school, she is so overwise.
But, gentle girl, if thou wilt forsake
The pinner, and be my love, I will advance thee high:
to dignify those hairs of amber hue,
I will grace them with a chaplet made of pearl,
Set with choice rubies, sparks, and diamonds,
Planted upon a velvet hood to hide that head,
Wherein two sapphires burn like sparkling fire:
This will I do, fair Bettris, and far more,
If thou wilt love the Lord of Doncaster.

sp.speaker: Bettris.
sp.l: Heigh ho, my heart is in a higher place,
Perhaps on the Earl, if that be he,
See where he comes, or angry or in love;
for why, his colour looketh discontent.

sp.speaker: Kendall.
sp.l: Come, Nick, follow me.

body.stage: Enter the Earle of Kendall and Nicholas Mannering.

sp.speaker: Bonfild.
sp.l: how now, my Lord? what news?

sp.speaker: Kendall.
sp.l: Such news, Bonfild, as will make thee laugh,
And fret thy fill, to hear how Nick was used:
Why, the Justices stand on their terms;
Nick, as you know, is haughty in his words;
He laid the law unto the Justices,
With threatening braves, that one looked on another,
Ready to stoop: but that a churl came in,
One George a Greene, the pinner of the town,
And with his dagger drawn laid hands on Nick,
And by no beggars swore that we were traitors,
Rent our Commission, and upon a brave,
Made Nick to eat the seals, or brooke the stab:
Poor Mannering afraid, came posting hither straight.

sp.speaker: Bettris.
sp.l: O lovely George, fortune be still thy friend,
And as thy thoughts be high, so be thy mind,
in all accords, even to thy hearts desire.

sp.speaker: Bonfild.
sp.l: What says fair Bettris?

sp.speaker: Grimes.
sp.l: My Lord, she is praying for George a Greene:
He is the man, and she will none but him.

sp.speaker: Bonfild.
sp.l: But him? why, look on me, my girl:
Thou knowest, that yesternight I courted thee,
And swore at my return to wed with thee:
Then tell me, love, shall I have all thy fair?

sp.speaker: Bettris.
sp.l: I care not for Earl, nor yet for Knight,
Nor Baron that is so bold:
for George a Greene the merry pinner,
He hath my heart in hold.

sp.speaker: Bonfild.
sp.l: Bootless, my Lord, are many vain replies.
Let us hie us to Wakefield, and send her the pinners head.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: It shall be so. Grime, gramercy,
Shut up thy daughter, bridle her affects,
Let me not miss her when I make return:
Therefore look to her, as to thy life, good Grime.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.l: I warrant you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ken.
sp.l: And Bettris, leave a base pinner, for to love an Earl.
Fain would I see this pinner George a Greene.
It shall be thus:
Nick Mannering shall lead on the battle,
And we three will go to Wakefield in some disguise:
But howsoever, I will have his head today .

body.stage: Enter the King of Scots, Lord Humes, with souldiers and Iohnie.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why, Iohnie: then the Earl of Kendall is blithe,
And hath brave men that troupe along with him.

sp.speaker: Iohnie.
sp.l: Aye marie, my liege, and hath good men
that come along with him,
And vows to meet you at Scrasblesea, God willing.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: If good saint Andrewe lend King Iame leave,
I will be with him at the pointed day.
But soft: whose pretty boy art thou?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Sir, I am son unto Sir Iohn a Barley,
Eldest and all that ere my mother had,
Edward my name.

sp.speaker: Iame.
sp.l: And whither art thou going, pretty Ned?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: to seek some birds, and kill them, if I can:
And now my schoolmaster is also gone:
so have I liberty to ply my bow:
for when he comes, I stir not from my book.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Lord Humes, but mark the visage of this child;
by him I guess the beauty of his mother:
None but Laeda could breed Helena.
Tell me, Ned, who is within with thy mother.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Not but herself and household servants, sir:
If you would speak with her, knock at this gate.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Iohnie, knock at that gate.

body.stage: Enter Iane a Barley vpon the walles.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: O, I am betrayed: what multitudes be these?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: fear not, fair Iane: for all these men are mine,
And all thy friends, if thou be friend to me:
I am thy lover Iames the King of Scots,
that oft have sued and wooed with many letters,
Painting my outward passions with my pen,
When as my inward soul did bleed for woe:
Little regard was given to my suit,
But happily thy husbands presence wrought it:
Therefore, sweet Iane, I fitted me to time;
And hearing that thy husband was from home,
Am come to crave what long I have desired.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Nay, soft you, sir you get no entrance here,
that seek to wrong sir Iohn a Barley so,
And offer such dishonour to my mother.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Why, what dishonour, Ned?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Though young, yet often have I heard My father say,
no greater wrong than to be made cuckold,
Were I of age, or were my body strong,
Were he ten Kings, I would shoot him to the heart,
that should attempt to give sir Iohn the horn.
Mother, let him not come in,
I will go lie at Jockey Millers house.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Stay him.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Aye , well said, Ned, thou hast given the King
His answer:
for were the ghost of Caesar on the earth,
Wrapped in the wonted glory of his honour,
He should not make me wrong my husband so:
But good King Iames is pleasant, as I guess,
And means to try what humour I am in,
Else would he never have brought an host of men,
to have them witness of his Scottish lust.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Iane, in faith, Iane.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: never reply: for I protest by the highest Holy God,
that doometh just revenge for things amiss,
King Iames of all men shall not have my love.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Then list to me, Saint Andrewe be my boot,
But I will raze thy castle to the very ground,
unless thou open the gate, and let me in.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: I fear thee not, King Iamie, do thy worst:
This castle is too strong for thee to scale:
Besides, tomorrow will sir Iohn come home.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Well, Iane, since thou disdainest King Iames love,
I will draw thee on with sharpe and deep extremes:
for by my fathers soul, this brat of thine
Shall perish here before thine eyes,
unless thou open the gate, and let me in.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: O deep extremes: my heart begins to break:
My little Ned looks pale for fear.
Cheer thee, my boy, I will do much for thee.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: But not so much, as to dishonour me.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: And if thou diest, I cannot live, sweet Ned.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Then die with honour, mother, dying chaste.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: I am armed:
My husbands love, his honour, and his fame,
Joins victory by virtue.
now, King Iames, if mothers tears cannot allay thine ire,
Then butcher him, for I will never yield:
The son shall die, before I wrong the father.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Why then he dies.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.l: My Lord, Musgroue is at hand.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: who, Musgroue? The devil he is. Come, My horse.

body.stage: Enter olde Musgroue with King Iames prisoner.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: now, King Iames, thou art my prisoner.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Not thine, but fortunes prisoner.

sp.speaker: Cuddie.
sp.l: Father, the field is ours: their colours we have seized:
And Humes is slain: I slew him hand to hand.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: God and Saint George.

sp.speaker: Cuddie.
sp.l: O father, I am sore athirst.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Come in, young Cuddie, come and drink thy fill:
Bring in King Iame with you as a guest:
for all this broil was cause he could not enter.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: The sweet content of men that live in love,
Breeds fretting humours in a restless mind,
And fancy being checked by fortunes spite,
Grows too impatient in her sweet desires:
Sweet to those men whom love leads on to bliss,
But sour to me, whose hap is still amiss.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Marie amen, sir.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Sir, what do you cry, Amen at?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Why, did not you talk of love ?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: how do you know that?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Well, though I say it that should not say it,
There are few fellows in our parish,
so nettled with love, as I have been of late.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Sirrah, I thought no less, when the other morning,
You rose so early to go to your wenches.
Sir, I had thought you had gone about my honest business.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Trow you have hit it: for master, be it known to you,
There is some good will betwixt Madge the Sousewife, And I,
Marie she hath another lover.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Canst thou brooke any rivals in thy love?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: A rider? no, he is a sow gelder, and goes afoot.
But Madge pointed to meet me in your wheat close.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: Well, did she meet you there?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: never make question of that:
And first I saluted her with a green gown,
And after fell as hard a wooing,
As if the Priest had been at our backs, to have married us.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: What, did she grant?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Did she grant? never make question of that:
And she gave me a shirt collar,
Wrought over with no counterfeit stuff.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: What, was it gold?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Nay, it was better than gold.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: What was it?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Right Couentrie blew,
who had no sooner come there, but wot you who came by.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: no, who?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Clim the sow gelder.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: Came he by?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: He spied Madge and I sit together,
He leapt from his horse, laid his hand on his dagger, and Began to swear.
Now I seeing he had a dagger,
And I nothing but this twig in my hand,
I gave him fair words and said nothing.
He comes to me and takes me by the bosom,
You whoreson shoe, said he, hold my horse,
And look he take no cold in his feet.
no marie shall he sir, quoth I,
I will lay my cloak underneath him:
I took my cloak, spread it all along,
And his horse on the midst of it.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: Thou clown, didst thou set his horse upon Thy cloak?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Aye , but mark how I served him:
Madge and he was no sooner gone down into the ditch,
But I plucked out my knife,
Cut four holes in my cloak, and made his horse stand
on the bare ground.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: it was well done: now sir, go and survey my fields:
If you find any cattle in the corn, to pound with them.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: And if I find any in the pound,
I shall turn them out.

body.stage: Enter the Earle of Kendal, Lord Bonfield, sir Gilbert, all disguised, with a traine of men.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Now we have put the horses in the corn,
Let us stand in some corner for to hear,
What braving terms the pinner will breathe,
When he spies our horses in the corn.

body.stage: Enter Iacke blowing of his horne.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: O master where are you? we have a prise.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: A prise, what is it?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Three goodly horses in our wheat close.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Three horses in our wheat close? whose be they?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.p: Marie that is a riddle to me: but they are there: Velvet horses, and I never saw such horses before. As my duty was, I put off my cap, and said as followeth: My masters, what do you make in our close? One of them hearing me ask what he made there, held up his head and neighed, and after his manner laughed as heartily as if a mare had been tied to his girdle. My masters, said I, it is no laughing matter; for if my master take you here, you go, as round as a top, to the pound. Another untoward jade hearing me threaten him to the pound, and to tell you of them, cast up both his heels, and let such a monstrous great fart; that was as much as in his language to say, A fart for the pound, and a fart for George a Greene. now I hearing this, put on my cap, blew my horn, called them all jades, and came to tell you.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: now sir, go and drive me those three horses to the pound.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: do you hear? I were best take a constable With me.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Why so?
Why, they being gentlemen's horses, may stand on their
Reputation, and will not obey me.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: go do as I bid you, sir.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Well, I may go.

body.stage: The Earle of Kendall, the Lord Bonfild, and sir Gilbert Armestrong meete them.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Whither away, sir?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Whither away? I am going to put the horses in the pound.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Sirrah, those three horses belong to us, and we put
Them in, and they must tarry there, and eat their fill.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Stay, I will go tell my master.
hear you, master? we have another prise:
Those three horses be in your wheat close still,
And here be three geldings more.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: What be these?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: These are the masters of the horses.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: now, gentlemen, I know not your degrees,
But more you cannot be, unless you be Kings,
Why wrong you us of Wakefield with your horses?
I am the pinner, and before you pass,
You shall make good the trespass they have done.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Peace, saucy mate, prate not to us:
I tell thee, pinner, we are gentlemen.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Why sir, so may I sir, although I give no arms.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Thou? how art thou a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: And such is my master, and he may give as good
Arms, as ever your great grandfather could give.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Pray thee let me hear how?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Marie my master my give for his arms,
The picture of April in a green jerkin,
With a rook on one fist, and an home on the other:
But my master gives his arms the wrong way;
for he gives the horn on his fist:
And your grandfather, because he would not lose his Arms,
Wears the horn on his own head.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Well pinner, since our horses be in,
in spite of thee they now shall feed their fill,
And eat until our leisures serve to go.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Now by my fathers soul,
Were good king Edwards horses in the corn,
They shall amend the scathe or kiss the pound,
Much more yours sir, whatsoever you be.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Why man, thou knowest not us,
we do belong to Henry Momford Earl of Kendal,
Men that before a month be full expired,
will be king Edwards betters in the land.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: King Edwards better, rebel, thou liest.

sp.speaker: Bonfild.
sp.l: Villain, what hast thou done? thou hast stroke
An Earl.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Why what care I? A poor man that is true,
Is better than an Earl, if he be false:
Traitors reap no better favours at my hands.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Aye , so methinks , but thou shalt dear abye this blow.
Now or never lay hold on the pinner.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: Stay, my Lords, let us parley on these broils:
Not Hercules against two, the proverb is,
Nor I against so great a multitude.
Had not your troupes come marching as they did,
I would have stopped your passage unto London:
But now I will fly to secret policy.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: What dost thou murmur, George?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Marie this, my Lord, I muse,
If thou be Henrie Momford Kendals Earl,
that thou wilt do poor George a Greene this wrong,
ever to match me with a troupe of men.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Why dost thou strike me then?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Why my Lord, measure me but by yourself:
Had you a man had served you long,
And heard your foe misuse you behind your back,
And would not draw his sword in your defence,
You would cashier him.
Much more, king Edwards is my king:
And before I will hear him so wronged,
I will die within this place,
And maintain good whatsoever I have said.
And if I speak not reason in this case,
What I have said I will maintain in this place.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: A pardon my Lord for this pinner,
for trust me he speaketh like a man of worth.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Well, George, wilt thou leave Wakefielde and Wend with me,
I will freely put up all and pardon thee.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: I my Lord, considering me one thing,
You will leave these arms and follow your good king.

sp.speaker: Ken.
sp.l: Why George, I rise not against king Edward,
But for the poor that is oppressed by wrong,
And if King Edward will redress the same,
I will not offer him disparagement,
But otherwise; and so let this suffice:
Thou hearest the reason why I rise in arms.
now wilt thou leave Wakefield, and wend with me,
I will make thee captain of a hardy band,
And when I have my will, dub thee a knight.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Why, my Lord, have you any hope to win?

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Why, there is a prophecy doth say,
that King Iames and I shall meet at London,
And make the King vail bonner to us both.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: If this were true, my Lord, this were a mighty reason

sp.speaker: Ken.
sp.l: Why, it is a miraculous prophecy, and cannot fail.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Well, my Lord, you have almost turned me.
Ienkin, come hither.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: go your ways home, sir,
And drive me those three horses home unto my house,
And power them them down a bushel of good oats.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Well, I will. Must I give these scurvy horses Oats?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: will it please you to command your train aside?

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Stand aside.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: now list to me:
Here in a wood not far from hence,
There dwells an old man in a cave alone,
that can foretell what fortunes shall befall you,
for he is greatly skilful in magic art :
Go you three to him early in the morning,
And question him if he says good,
Why then my Lord, I am the foremost man,
we will march up with your camp to London.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: George, thou honourest me in this:
But where shall we find him out?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: My man shall conduct you to the place:
But good my Lords tell me true what the wise man saith.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: that will I, as I am Earl of Kendal.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Why then, to honour George a Greene the more,
Vouchsafe a piece of beef at my poor house,
You shall have wafer cakes your fill,
A piece of beef hung up since Martilmas,
If that like you not, take what you bring for me.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Gramercies, George.

body.stage: Enter George a Greenes boy Wily, disguised like a woman to M. Grimes.

sp.speaker: Wily.
sp.l: O what is love? it is some mighty power,
Else could it never conquer George a Greene:
Here dwells a churl that keeps away his love ,
I know the worst and if I be espied,
it is but a beating, and if I by this means
Can get fair Bettris forth her fathers door,
It is enough, Venus for me, and all goes alone,
Be aiding to my wily enterprise.

body.stage: He knocks at the doore. Enter Grime.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: How now, who knocks there? what would you have ?
From whence came you? where do you dwell?

sp.speaker: Wily.
sp.l: I am, forsooth, a seamsters maid hard by,
that hath brought work home to your daughter.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.l: Nay, are you not some crafty quean,
that comes from George a Greene, that rascal,
With some letters to my daughter?
I will have you searched.

sp.speaker: Wily.
sp.l: Alas, sir, it is Hebrew unto me,
to tell me of George a Greene, or any other:
Search me good sir,
And if you find a letter about me,
Let me have the punishment that is due.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.l: Why are you muffled? I like you the worse for that.

sp.speaker: Wily.
sp.l: I am not, sir, ashamed to show my face,
Yet loath I am my cheeks should take the air,
Not that I am chary of my beauties hue,
But that I am troubled with the toothache sore.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.l: A pretty wench of smiling countenance,
Old men can like, although they cannot love,
Aye , and love, though not so brief as young men can.
Well, go in, my wench, and speak with my daughter.
I wonder much at the Earl of Kendall,
Being a mighty man, as still he is,
Yet for to be a traitor to his king,
Is more than God or man will well allow:
But what a fool am I to talk of him?
My mind is more here of the pretty lass:
Had she brought some forty pounds to town,
I could be content to make her my wife:
Yet I have heard it in a proverb said,
He that is old, and marries with a lass,
Lies but at home, and proves himself an ass.
sp.stage: Enter Bettris in Wilies apparell to Grime.
sp.l: How now, my wench, how is it? what not a word?
Alas, poor soul, the toothache plagues her sore.
Well, my wench, here is an Angel for to buy thee pins,
And I pray thee use mine house,
The oftener the more welcome: farewell.

sp.speaker: Bettris.
sp.l: O blessed love, and blessed fortune both.
But Bettris, stand not here to talk of love,
But hie thee straight unto thy George a Greene:
never went Roe buck swifter on the downs,
Than I will trip it till I see my George.

body.stage: Enter the Earle of Kendall, L.Bonfield, sir Gilbert,and Ienkin the clowne.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Come away Ienkin.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Come, here is his house. Where be you, ho?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: who knocks there?

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: here are two or three poor men, father,
Would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: Pray give your man leave to lead me forth.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: go, Ienkin, fetch him forth.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Come, old man.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Father, here is three poor men come to question
Thee a word in secrete that concerns their lives .

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Say on my sons.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Father, I am sure you hear the news,
How that the Earl of Kendal wars against the king,
Now father we three are Gentlemen by birth,
But younger brethren that want revenues,
And for the hope we have to be preferred,
If that we knew that we shall win,
we will march with him:
If not, we will not march a foot to London more.
Therefore good father, tell us what shall happen,
Whether the King or the Earl of Kendal shall win.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: The king, my son.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Art thou sure of that?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: I, as sure as thou art Henry Momford,
The one Lord Bonfild, the other sir Gilbert.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Why this is wondrous, being blind of sight,
His deep perseverance should be such to know us.

sp.speaker: Gilb.
sp.l: Magic is mighty, and foretelleth great matters:
in deed Father, here is the Earl come to see thee,
And therefore good father fable not with him.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Welcome is the Earl to my poor cell,
And so are you my Lords: but let me counsel you,
to leave these wars against your king,
And live in quiet.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Father, we come not for advice in war,
But to know whether we shall win or lose.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: Lose gentle Lords, but not by good king Edward:
A baser man shall give you all the foil.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Aye marie father, what man is that?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Poor George a Greene the pinner.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: What shall he?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Pull all your plumes, and sore dishonour you.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: He, as how?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Nay, the end tries all, but so it will fall out.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: But so it shall not by my honour Christ.
I will raise my camp, and fire Wakefield town,
And take that servile pinner George a Greene,
And butcher him before king Edwards face.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Good my Lord be not offended,
for I speak no more than art reveals to me:
And for greater proof,
give your man leave to fetch me my staff.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Ienkin, fetch him his walking staff.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Here is your walking staff.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: I will proud it good upon your carcasses:
A wiser wizard never met you yet,
Nor one that better could foredoom your fall:
Now I have singled you here alone,
I care not though you be three to one.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Villain, hast thou betrayed us?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: Momford, thou liest, never was I traitor yet;
only devised this guile to draw you on,
for to be combatants.
Now conquer me, and then march on to London:
But shall go hard, but I will hold you task.

sp.speaker: Gilb.
sp.l: Come, my Lord, cheerily, I will kill him hand to hand.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: A thousand pound to him that strikes that stroke.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: Then give it me, for I will have thee first.

body.stage: Here they fight, George kils sir Gilbert,and takes the other two prisoners.

sp.speaker: Bonfild.
sp.l: Stay, George, we do appeal.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: to whom.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Why, to the king:
for rather had we bide what he appoints,
Than here be murthered by a servile groom.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: What wilt thou do with us ?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: even as Lord Bonfild wist,
You shall unto the king,
And for that purpose see where the Justice is placed.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Now, my Lord of Kendal, where be all your threats?
even as the cause, so is the combat fallen,
Else one could never have conquered three.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: I pray thee, Woodroffe, do not twit me:
If I have faulted, I must make amends.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Master Woodroffe, here is not a place for many Words,
I beseech ye sir, discharge all his soldiers,
that every man may go home unto his own house.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.l: It shall be so, what wilt thou do George?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Master Woodroffe, look to your charge,
Leave me to myself.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Come, my Lords.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Here sit thou, George, wearing a willow wreath,
As one despairing of thy beauteous love:
Fie George no more,
Pine not away for that which cannot be:
I cannot joy in any earthly bliss,
so long as I do want my Bettris.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: who see a master of mine?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: How now, sirrah, whither away?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Whither away? why who do you take me to be?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: Why Ienkin my man.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: I was so once in deed, but now the case is altered.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: I pray thee, as how?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Were not you a fortune teller today ?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: Well, what of that?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: so sure am I become a juggler.
What will you say if I juggle your sweet heart?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Peace, prating losel, her jealous father
Doth wait over her with such suspicious eyes,
that if a man but dally by her feet,
He thinks it straight, a witch to charm his daughter.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Well, what will you give me, if I bring her hither?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: A suit of green, and twenty crowns besides.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Well, by your leave, give me room,
You must give me something that you have lately worn.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Here is a gown, will that serve you?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Aye , this will serve me: keep out of my circle,
lest you be torn in pieces with she devils:
Mistress Bettris, once, twice, thrice.

body.stage: He throwes the ground in, and she comes out.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: O is this no cunning?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Is this my love, or is it but her shadow?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Aye this is the shadow, but here is the substance.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Tell me sweet love, what good fortune
Brought thee hither:
for one it was that favoured George a Greene.

sp.speaker: Bettris.
sp.l: Both love and fortune brought me to my George,
in whose sweet sight is all my hearts content.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Tell me sweet love, how camest thou from thy Fathers?

sp.speaker: Bettris.
sp.l: A willing mind hath many slips in love:
It was not I, but Wily thy sweet boy.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: And where is Wily now?

sp.speaker: Bettris.
sp.l: in my apparel in my chamber still.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Ienkin, come hither: go to Bradford,
And listen out your fellow Wily.
Come, Bettris, let us in,
And in my cottage we will sit and talk .

body.stage: Enter King Edward, the king of Scots, Lord Warwicke, yong Cuddy, and their traine.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Brother of Scotland, I do hold it hard,
Seeing a league of truce was late confirmed
Twixt you and me, without displeasure offered,
You should make such invasion in my land,
The vows of kings should be as oracles,
Not blemished with the stain of any breach,
Chiefly where fealty and homage willeth it.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Brother of England, rub not the sore afresh,
My conscience grieves me for my deep misdeed,
I have the worst, of thirty thousand men,
There scaped not full five thousand from the field.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Gramercy, Musgroue, else it had gone hard.
Cuddie, I will quite thee well ere we two part

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: But had not his old Father William Musgroue
played twice the man, I had not now been here,
A stronger man I seldom felt before,
But one of more resolute valiance,
Treads not I think upon the English ground.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I wot well, Musgroue shall not lose his hire.

sp.speaker: Cuddie.
sp.l: And it please your grace, my father was
Five score and three at Midsummer last past,
Yet had king Iamie been as good as George a Greene,
Yet Billy Musgroue would have fought with him.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: As George a Greene, I pray thee, Cuddie,
Let me question thee,
Much have I heard since I came to my crown,
Many in manner of a proverb say,
Were he as good as George a Green, I would strike him sure:
I pray thee tell me, Cuddie, canst thou inform me,
What is that George a Greene.

sp.speaker: Cuddie.
sp.l: Know, my Lord, I never saw the man,
But mickle talk is of him in the Country,
They say he is the Pinner of Wakefield town,
But for his other qualities, I let alone.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: May it please your grace, I know the man too well.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Too well, why so, Warwicke?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: for once he swinged me, till my bones did ache.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Why, dares he strike an Earl?

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: An Earl my Lord, nay he will strike a king,
Be it not king Edward.
for stature he is framed,
like to the picture of stout Hercules,
And for his carriage passeth Robin Hood.
The boldest Earl or Baron of your land,
that offereth scathe unto the town of Wakefield,
George will arrest his pledge unto the pound,
And who so resisteth bears away the blows,
for he himself is good enough for three.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Why this is wondrous, my Lord of Warwicke,
Sore do I long to see this George a Greene.
But leaving him, what shall we do, my Lord,
for to subdue the rebels in the North?
They are now marching up to Doncaster.

body.stage: Enter one with the Earle of Kendal prisoner.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Soft, who have we there?

sp.speaker: Cuddie.
sp.l: Here is a traitor, the Earl of Kendal.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Aspiring traitor, how darest thou once
Cast thine eyes upon thy Sovereign,
that honoured thee with kindness and with favour?
But I will make thee buy this treason dear.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Reply not, traitor.
Tell me, Cuddy, whose deed of honour
Won the victory against this rebel.

sp.speaker: Cuddy.
sp.l: George a Greene the Pinner of Wakefield.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: George a Greene, now shall I hear news
Certain what this Pinner is:
Discourse it briefly, Cuddy, how it befell.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.l: Kendall and Bonfild, with sir Gilbert Armstrong,
Came to Wakefield Town disguised.
And there spoke ill of your grace,
which George but hearing, field them at his feet,
And had not rescue come into the place,
George had slain him in his close of wheat.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: But Cuddy, canst thou not tell
Where I might give and grant some thing,
that might please, and highly gratify the pinners thoughts?

sp.speaker: Cuddie.
sp.l: This at their parting George did say to me,
If the king vouchsafe of this my service,
Then gentle Cuddie kneel upon thy knee,
And humbly crave a boon of him for me.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Cuddie, what is it?

sp.speaker: Cuddie.
sp.l: It is his will your grace would pardon them,
And let them live although they have offended.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I think the man striveth to be glorious.
Well, George hath craved it, and it shall be granted,
which none but he in England should have gotten.
live Kendall, but as prisoner,
so shalt thou end thy days within the tower.

sp.speaker: Kend.
sp.l: Gracious is Edward to offending subjects.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: My Lord of Kend, you are welcome to the court.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Nay, but ill come as it falls out now,
Aye , ill come in deed, were it not for George a Greene,
But gentle king, for so you would aver,
And Edwards betters, I salute you both,
And here I vow by good Saint George,
You will gain but little when your sums are counted.
I sore do long to see this George a Greene:
And for because I never saw the North,
I will forthwith go see it:
And for that to none I will be known,
we will disguise ourselves and steal down secretly,
Thou and I king Iames, Cuddie, and two or three,
And make a merry journey for a month.
Away then, conduct him to the tower.
Come on king Iames my heart must needs be merry,
If fortune make such havoc of our foes.

body.stage: Enter Robin Hood, Mayd" Marian, Scarlet, and Much the Millers sonne.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Why is not lovely Marian blithe of cheer?
What ails my Lemman that she gins to lower?
Say good Marian why art thou so sad.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: Nothing, my Robin, grieves me to the heart,
But whensoever I do walk abroad,
I hear no songs but all of George a Greene,
Bettris his fair Lemman passeth me.
And this my Robin galls my very soul.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Content, what wreaks it us though George a
Greene be stout,
so long as he doth proffer us no scathe?
Envy doth seldom hurt but to itself,
And therefore, Marian, smile upon thy Robin.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: never will Marian smile upon her Robin,
Nor lie with him under the green wood shade,
Till that thou go to Wakefield on a green,
And beat the Pinner for the love of me.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Content thee, Marian, I will ease thy grief,
My merry men and I will thither stray,
And here I vow that for the love of thee,
I will beat George a Greene, or he shall beat me.

sp.speaker: Scarlet.
sp.l: As I am Scarlet, next to little Iohn,
One of the boldest yeomen of the crew,
so will I wend with Robin all along,
And try this Pinner what he dares do.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: As I am Much the Millers son,
that left my Mill to go with thee,
And nil repent that I have done,
This pleasant life contenteth me,
in aught I may to do thee good,
I will live and die with Robin Hood.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: And Robin, Marian she will go with thee,
to see fair Bettris how bright she is of blee.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Marian, thou shalt go with thy Robin.
Bend up your bows, and see your strings be tight,
The arrows keen, and every thing be ready,
And each of you a good bat on his neck,
Able to lay a good man on the ground.

sp.speaker: Scarlet.
sp.l: I will have Friar Tucks.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: I will have little Iohns.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: I will have one made of an ashen plunk,
Able to bear a bout or two.
Then come on, Marian, let us go ,
for before the Sun doth show the morning day,
I will be at Wakefield to see this Pinner George a Greene.

body.stage: Enter a Shoomaker sitting vpon the stage at worke, Ienkin to him.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: My masters, he that hath neither meat nor money,
And hath lost his credit with the Alewife,
for any thing I know, may go supperless to bed.
But soft who is here? here is a Shoemaker:
He knows where is the best Ale.
Shoemaker, I pray thee tell me,
Where is the best Ale in the town?

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: Afore, afore, follow thy nose:
At the sign of the eggshell.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Come Shoemaker, if thou wilt,
And take thy part of a pot.

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: Sirrah, down with your staff,
down with your staff.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Why how now, is the fellow mad?
I pray thee tell me, why should I hold down my staff?

sp.speaker: Shooma.
sp.l: You will down with him, will you not sir?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Why tell me wherefore?

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: My friend, this is the town of merry Wakefield,
And here is a custom held,
that none shall pass with his staff on his shoulders,
But he must have a bout with me,
And so shall you sir.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: And so will not I sir.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: that will I try. Barking dogs bite not the sorest.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: I would to God, I were once well rid of him.

sp.speaker: Shooma.
sp.l: Now, what, will you down with your staff?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Why you are not in earnest, are you?

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: If I am not, take that.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: You whoreson cowardly scab,
It is but the part of a clapperdudgeon,
to strike a man in the street.
But darest thou walk to the towns end with me?

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: Aye that I dare do: but stay till I lay in my
Tools, and I will go with thee to the towns end Presently.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: I would I knew how to be rid of this fellow.

sp.speaker: Shoom.
sp.l: Come sir, will you go to the towns end now sir?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: I sir, come.
Now we are at the towns end, what say you now?

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: Marry come, let us even have a bout.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: ha, stay a little, hold thy hands, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: Why what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Faith I am under pinner of a town,
And there is an order, which if I do not keep,
I shall be turned out of mine office.

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: What is that, sir?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Whensoever I go to fight with any body,
I use to flourish my staff thrice about my head
Before I strike, and then show no favour.

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: Well sir, and till then I will not strike thee.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: well sir, here is once, twice, here is my hand,
I will never do it the third time.

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: Why then I see we shall not fight.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Faith no: come, I will give thee two pots
Of the best Ale, and be friends.

sp.speaker: Shoomak.
sp.l: Faith I see it is as hard to get water out of a flint,
As to get him to have a bout with me:
Therefore I will enter into him for some good cheer:
My friend, I see thou art a faint hearted fellow,
Thou hast no stomach to fight,
Therefore let us go to the Alehouse and drink.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Well, content, go thy ways and say thy prayers,
Thou scapest my hands today .

body.stage: Enter George a Greene and Bettris.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Tell me sweet love, how is thy mind content,
What canst thou brooke to live with George a Greene?

sp.speaker: Bettris.
sp.l: O George, how little pleasing are these words?
Came I from Bradford for the love of thee?
And left my father for so sweet a friend?
Here will I live until my life do end.

body.stage: Enter Robin Hood, and Marian, and his traine.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Happy am I to have so sweet a love .
But what are these come tracing here along?

sp.speaker: Bettris.
sp.l: Three men come striking through the corn,
My love.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: back again, you foolish travellers,
for you are wrong, and may not wend this way.

sp.speaker: Robin Hood.
sp.l: that were great shame.
Now by my soul, proud sir,
we be three tall yeomen, and thou art but one:
Come, we will forward in despite of him.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Leap the ditch, or I will make you skip.
What, cannot the hie way serve your turn,
But you must make a path over the corn?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Why, art thou mad? darest thou encounter three?
we are no babes, man, look upon our limbs.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Sirrah, the biggest limbs have not the stoutest hearts.
Were ye as good as Robin Hood, and his three merry men,
I will drive you back the same way that ye came.
Be ye men, ye scorn to encounter me all at once,
But be ye cowards, set upon me all three,
And try the Pinner what he dares perform.

sp.speaker: Scarlet.
sp.l: Were thou as high in deeds,
As thou art haughty in words,
Thou well mightst be a champion for a king:
But empty vessels have the loudest sounds,
And cowards prattle more than men of worth.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Sirrah, darest thou try me?

sp.speaker: Scarlet.
sp.l: Aye sirrah, that I dare.

body.stage: They fight,and George a Greene beats him.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: How now? what art thou down?
Come, sir, I am next.

body.stage: They fight,and George a Greene beates him.

sp.speaker: Robin Hood.
sp.l: Come sirrah, now to me, spare me not,
for I will not spare thee.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Make no doubt, I will be as liberal to thee.

sp.speaker: Robin Hood.
sp.l: Stay, George, for here I do protest,
Thou art the stoutest champion that ever I laid Hands upon.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Soft you sir, by your leave you lie,
You never yet laid hands on me.

sp.speaker: Robin Hood.
sp.l: George, wilt thou forsake Wakefield,
And go with me,
Two liveries will I give thee every year,
And forty crowns shall be thy fee.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Why, who art thou?

sp.speaker: Robin Hood.
sp.l: Why, Robin Hood:
I am come hither with my Marian,
And these my yeomen for to visit thee.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Robin Hood? next to king Edward
Art thou lief to me:
Welcome, sweet Robin, welcome, maid Marian,
And welcome, you my friends.
will you to my poor house,
You shall have wafer cakes your fill,
A piece of beef hung up since Martlemas,
Mutton and veal, if this like you not,
Take that you find, or that you bring for me.

sp.speaker: Robin Hood.
sp.l: God-a-mercies, good George,
I will be thy guest today .

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Robin, therein thou honourest me.
I will lead the way.

body.stage: Enter King Edward, and King Iames disguised, with two slaues.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Come on, king Iames, now we are
Thus disguised,
There is none (I know) will take us to be kings:
I think we are now in Bradford,
Where all the merry shoemakers dwell.

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: down with your staves, my friends,
down with them.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: down with our staves? I pray thee, why so?

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: My friend, I see thou art a stranger here,
Else wouldst thou not have questioned of the thing.
This is the town of merry Bradford,
And here hath been a custom kept of old,
that none may bear his staff upon his neck,
But trail it all along throughout the town,
unless they mean to have a bout with me.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: But hear you sir, hath the king
Granted you this custom?

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: King or Kaiser, none shall pass this way,
Except King Edward,
no not the stoutest groom that haunts his court:
Therefore down with your staves.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: What were we best to do?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Faith, my Lord, they are stout fellows.
And because we will see some sport,
we will trail our staves.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Hearest thou, my friend?
Because we are men of peace and travellers,
we are content to trail our staves.

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: The way lies before you, go along.

body.stage: Enter Robin Hood and George a Greene disguised.

sp.speaker: Robin Hood.
sp.l: See George, two men are passing
Through the town,
Two lusty men, and yet they trail their staves.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Robin, they are some peasants
Tricked in yeoman's weeds. Holla, you two travellers.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Call you us, sir?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Aye , you. Are ye not big enough to bear
Your bats upon your necks,
But you must trail them along the streets?

sp.speaker: Edwar.
sp.l: Yes sir, we are big enough, but here is a custom
Kept, that none may pass his staff upon his neck,
unless he trail it at the weapons point.
Sir, we are men of peace, and love to sleep
in our whole skins, and therefore quietness is best.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Base minded peasants, worthless to be men,
What, have you bones and limbs to strike a blow,
And be your hearts so faint, you cannot fight?
Wert not for shame, I would shrub your shoulders well,
And teach you manhood against another time.

sp.speaker: Shoom.
sp.l: Well preached sir Jack, down with your staff.

sp.speaker: Edwar.
sp.l: Do you hear my friends? and you be wise,
Keep down your staves,
for all the town will rise upon you.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Thou speakest like an honest quiet fellow.
But hear you me, in spite of all the swains
Of Bradford town, bear me your staves upon your necks,
Or to begin withal, I will baste you both so well,
You were never better basted in your lives.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: we will hold up our staves.

body.stage: George a Greene fights with the Shoomakers, and beates them all downe.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: What, have you any more?
Call all your town forth, cut, and long-tail.

body.stage: The Shoomakers spy George a Greene.

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: What, George a Greene, is it you?
A plague found you,
I think you longed to swing me well.
Come George, we will crush a pot before we part.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: A pot you slave, we will have an hundred.
here, Will Perkins, take my purse,
Fetch me a stand of Ale, and set in the Market place,
that all may drink that are athirst this day,
for this is for a fee to welcome Robin Hood
to Bradford town.

body.stage: They bring out the stande of ale, and fall a drinking.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Here Robin, sit thou here; for thou art the best man
At the board this day.
You that are strangers, place yourselves where you will.
Robin, here is a carouse to good King Edwards self,
And they that love him not, I would we had
The basting of them a little.

body.stage: Enter the Earle of Warwicke with other noble men, bringing out the Kings garments: then George a Greene and the rest kneele downe to the King.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Come, masters, all fellows.
Nay, Robin, you are the best man at the board today .
Rise up George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Nay, good my Liege, ill nurtured we were then:
Though we Yorkeshire men be blunt of speech,
And little skilled in court, or such quaint fashions,
Yet nature teacheth us duty to our king:
Therefore I humbly beseech you pardon George a Green.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: And good my Lord, a pardon for poor Robin,
And for us all a pardon, good King Edward.

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: I pray you, a pardon for the Shoemakers.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I frankly grant a pardon to you all.
And, George a Greene, give me thy hand:
There is none in England that shall do thee wrong.
even from my court I came to see thyself ;
And now I see that same speaks naught but truth.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: I humbly thank your royal Majesty.
that which I did against the Earl of Kendal,
It was but a subjects duty to his Sovereign,
And therefore little merit such good words.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: But ere I go, I will grace thee with good deeds.
Say what King Edward may perform,
And thou shalt have it, being in Englands bounds.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: I have a lovely Lemman,
As bright of blee as is the silver moon,
And old Grimes her father will not let her match
With me, because I am a Pinner,
Although I love her, and she me dearly.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Where is she?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: At home at my poor house,
And vows never to marry unless her father
give consent, which is my great grief, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: If this be all, I will dispatch it straight,
I will send for Grime and force him give his grant,
He will not deny king Edward such a suit.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Ho, who saw a master of mine?
O he is gotten into company, and a body should rake
Hell for company.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Peace, ye slave, see where King Edward is.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: George, what is he?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: I beseech your grace pardon him, he is my man.

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: Sirrah, the king hath been drinking with us,
And did pledge us too.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Hath he so? kneel, I dub you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: Beg it of the King, Ienkin.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: I will. I beseech your worship grant me one thing.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Hark in your ear.

body.stage: He whispers the king in the eare.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: go your ways and do it.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Come down on your knees, I have got it.

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: Let us hear what it is first.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: Marry, because you have drunk with the king,
And the king hath so graciously pledged you,
You shall be no more called Shoemakers.
But you and yours to the worlds end,
Shall be called the trade of the gentle craft.

sp.speaker: Shoomaker.
sp.l: I beseech your majesty reform this
which he hath spoken.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: I beseech your worship consume this
which he hath spoken.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Confirm it, you would say.
Well, he hath done it for you, it is sufficient.
Come, George, we will go to Grime,
And have thy love.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: I am sure your worship will abide:
for yonder is coming old Musgroue,
And mad Cuddie his son.
Master, my fellow Wilie comes dressed like a woman,
And master Grime will marry Wilie: here they come.

body.stage: Enter Musgroue and Cuddie, and master Grime, Wilie, Mayd Marian and Bettris.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: which is thy old father, Cuddie?

sp.speaker: Cuddie.
sp.l: This, if it please your majesty.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Ah old Musgroue, kneel up,
It fits not such gray hairs to kneel.

sp.speaker: Musgroue.
sp.l: Long live my Sovereign,
Long and happy be his days:
Vouchsafe, my gracious Lord, a simple gift,
At Billy Musgroues hand:
King Iames at Meddellom castle gave me this,
This won the honour, and this give I thee.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: God-a-mercy, Musgroue, for this friendly gift,
And for thou felledest a king with this same weapon,
This blade shall here dub valiant Musgroue knight.

sp.speaker: Musgr.
sp.l: Alas what hath your highness done? I am poor.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: to mend thy living take thou Meddellom castle,
The hold of both: and if thou want living, complain,
Thou shalt have more to maintain thine estate.
George, which is thy love?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: This, if please your majesty.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Art thou her aged father?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.l: I am, if it like your majesty.

sp.speaker: Edwar.
sp.l: And wilt not give thy daughter unto George?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.l: Yes, my Lord, if he will let me marry
With this lovely lass.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: What sayst thou, George?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: With all my heart, my Lord, I give consent.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.l: Then do I give my daughter unto George.

sp.speaker: Wilie.
sp.l: Then shall the marriage soon be at an end.
Witness, my Lord, if that I be a woman,
for I am Wilie, boy to George a Greene,
who for my master wrought this subtle shift.

sp.speaker: Edwar.
sp.l: What, is it a boy? what sayst thou to this Grime?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.l: Marry, my Lord, I think this boy hath
More knavery, than all the world besides.
Yet am I content that George shall both have
My daughter and my lands.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Now George, it rests I gratify thy worth:
And therefore here I do bequeath to thee,
in full possession half that Kendal hath,
And what as Bradford holds of me in chief,
I give it frankly unto thee forever.
Kneel down George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: What will your majesty do?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Dub thee a knight, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: I beseech your grace, grant me one thing.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Then let me live and die a yeoman still:
so was my father, so must live his son.
for it is more credit to men of base degree,
to do great deeds, than men of dignity.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Well, be it so George.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: I beseech your grace dispatch with me,
And set down my ransom.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: George a Greene, set down the king of Scots His ransom.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: I beseech your grace pardon me,
It passeth my skill.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Do it, the honour is thine.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Then let king Iames make good
Those towns which he hath burnt upon the borders,
give a small pension to the fatherless,
Whose fathers he cause murthered in those wars,
Put in pledge for these things to your grace,
And so return. King Iames, are you content.

sp.speaker: Iamie.
sp.l: I am content: and like your majesty,
And will leave good castles in security.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I crave no more. Now George a Greene,
I will to thy house: and when I have supped, I will go to ask,
And see if Iane a Barley be so fair,
As good King Iames reports her for to be.
And for the ancient custom of Vail staff keep it still,
Claim privilege from me:
If any ask a reason why? or how?
Say, English Edward vailed his staff to you.
